argumentText:
Let $p\in {\mathbb{R}}$ and $x\in{\mathbb{R}},\;|x|<1$ be given. We wish
to show that
$$(1+x)^p = \sum_{n=0}^\infty p^{\underline{n}}\; \frac{x^n}{n!},$$
where $p^{\underline{n}}$ denotes the $n{^{\text{th}}}$ falling
factorial of $p$.

The convergence of the series in the right-hand side of the above
equation is a straight-forward consequence of the ratio test. Set
$$f(x) = (1+x)^p.$$ and note that
$$f^{(n)}(x) = p^{\underline{n}}\, (1+x)^{p-n}.$$ The desired equality
now follows from Taylor’s Theorem. Q.E.D.
